paper_title.ja: 木工具による作業動作の三次元分析(第4報)木工技能熟練者と未熟練者のきりもみ動作の一比較事例

paper_title.en: Three-dimensional analysis of the work motion using woodworking tools IV. Comparison of the drilling motion with a Japanese gimlet (Yotsume-giri) of skilled and unskilled woodworker

description.en:
In this paper, three-dimensional motion analysis was introduced to observe body and tool motion in manual woodworking. The Japanese drill motion with a gimlet (a boring tool called yotsume-giri in Japanese) of skilled and unskilled woodworkers was investigated by three-dimensional cinematography. The results are as follows:
The skilled woodworker (right-handed person) had the line of both feet turned sideways to the right of the body. The unskilled woodworker had the line of both feet parallel to the body.
The sight line of the skilled woodworker passed between both arms to observe the position of the top of the bit. The sight line of the unskilled woodworker was located outside of the left arm to observe the position of the top of the bit. The skilled woodworker started the drill work from the top of the drill handle, but the unskilled woodworker started it from a position below the top of the drill handle. The range of drill hand work of the skilled woodworker was wider than that of the unskilled woodworker.
In case of the skilled woodworker, the characteristic drilling motion included movement of the upper half of the body by bending at the waist to enlarge the elbow joint angle. The characteristic drilling motion of the unskilled woodworker involved only bending of the forearm around the elbow joint.
The swing amplitude of the top of the axis (handle) of the drill was twice as large as that of the skilled woodworker.

木工具による作業動作の3次元分析(第2報)木工技能熟練者と未熟練者ののこぎりびき動作の比較

paper_title.en: Three-dimensional analysis of the work motion using woodworking tools III. Comparison of the nailing motion of skilled and unskilled woodworkers

description.en:
In this paper, a three-dimensional motion analysis theory and system have been introduced to observe and detect the action of operators in manual woodworking. The nailing motions of skilled and unskilled woodworkers were investigated with three-dimensional cinematography. The aim was to research the basic form of actions and the nature of the skills. The results are as follows:
1. The basic posture of the skilled worker during a nailing operation was to turn the body half sideways (right handed person) with the head located in behind and above the nail. The skilled worker's line of sight was midway between his arms, locating the position where he could observe and judge the hammering and nailing.
2. The nailing process from the beginning to end could be divided into three stages depending on the impact energy and function of the hammer. The operating motions of the skilled worker can be described as follows: The fixing and nailing motions consisting of the wrist raised to a small amplitude and height, are composed of stretching the elbow and bending the wrist in nailing stage, of changing the impact position of the hammer, and of hammering the whole nail into the board near the end of the nailing stage.
3. The difference in nailing operation between skilled and unskilled worker's was determined in this research by qualitative and quantitative analysis.

paper_title.en: Three-dimensional analyses of the work motion using woodworking tools II. Comparison of the sawing motions of skilled and unskilled woodworkers

description.en:
Using a three-dimensional analysis system, tests were made to investigate the sawing motion (placing the work piece on a work bench, holding the material firmly with the left hand and making a one-handed sawing motion with the right hand) by qualitative and quantitative analysis of the mechanism of each step of the work such as position and motion.
The skilled worker when sawing took an oblique stance, the forehead directly above and behind the saw blade in a position where he could ascertain the left or right inclination of the saw blade correctly. The right arm and the back and forth motion of the saw blade were almost in a vertical plane. Corresponding to the three stages of the operation, namely the beginning and the intermediate stages and the stage just before the end, there were three kinds of basic sawing motions. They consisted in the beginning of the operation of small, mincing pulling motions using the base end of the saw blade, during the intermediate stage of a backwards, large-scale, reciprocating pulling motion with the right elbow moving in smooth circular arcs, and just before the completion of the operation of reducing the angle of pull and mincing pulling motions. Also, the pulling angle of the saw blade during one cycle of the sawing motion was subjected to regular angular control according to each of the respective stages.
Comparing the work motions of skilled and unskilled persons, a lack of skill becomes strikingly clear mainly from the position of the forehead, and such points as the stability of the motion of the right arm, the extent of utilizing the length of the saw blade in correspondence to the three stages of sawing, and the irregularity of sawing speed and pulling angle.

paper_title.ja: かんな削り動作の類型図によるバイオメカニクス的動作の分析と分類(共著)

paper_title.en: BIOMECHANICAL MOTION ANALYSIS AND CLASSIFICATION BY TYPE DIAGRAM OF JAPANESE PLANING MOTION

description.en:
We have developed type diagrams based on five major elements of the Japanese planing motion. One purpose of a type diagram is to analytically compare the planing motion of skilled and unskilled woodworkers and to present the results graphically. The second purpose of a type diagram is to analyze the planing motion of unskilled woodworkers and to classify them into groups. The five major elements composing the type diagram are as follows: (1) The position of the knife in relation to the far end of the materal. (2) The standing position of the subject. (3) The magnitude of the pulling force and the downward pushing force. (4) The total horizontal waist movement of the subject. (5) The position of the knife in relation to the near end of the material.
Furthermore, each major element-is subclassified into several variations. Using the type diagram, we were able to easily and logically classify the Japanese planing motion.
